questions.text: When did Walt Whitman first publish his book of poetry titled 'Leaves of Grass'?
questions.explanation:
1855.

	On July 4, 1855, Walt Whitman had a book of poetry titled 'Leaves Of Grass' published. The poetry was criticized because of his usage of sex and the human body.

questions.text: Walt Whitman wrote several poems about a president. What president was Walt Whitman's hero?
questions.explanation:
Abraham Lincoln.

	Walt Whitman's most famous poem about former President Lincoln was "O Captain, My Captain". Walt wrote a section of poems titled 'Drum Taps' and 'President Lincoln's Burial Hymn' for President Lincoln.

questions.text: Which poet did Walt Whitman often read that inspired the book of poetry called 'Leaves of Grass'?
questions.explanation:
Ralph Emerson.

	After Walt read Ralph Waldo Emerson's poem titled "The Poet", he started working on 'Leaves of Grass'. Mr. Emerson read the poems and called it 'the most extraordinary piece of wit and wisdom America has yet contributed'.

questions.text:
What poem in 'Leaves Of Grass' does this line come from, "Only themselves understand themselves, and the like of themselves,   
as Souls only understand Souls"?
questions.explanation:
Perfections.

	This poem comes out of the section of 'Leaves Of Grass' titled 'Children of Adam'. The poem is only two lines long.

questions.text: Which one of the poems out of 'Leaves Of Grass' was Walt Whitman asked to drop from the book?
questions.explanation:
Spontaneous Me.

	After reading the selection of poems, Boston District Attorney Oliver Stevens requested that "Spontaneous Me" be taken out of the book because of what the poem meant. The poems "I Sing The Body Electric", "A Woman Waits for Me", and "To a Common Prostitute" were also requested of Whitman to be left out of the book. After Whitman refused, his publishing company dropped him. Soon after, he found another publisher by the name of Rees Welsh.

questions.text: What is the missing word in the following title of a poem in 'Leaves Of Grass': "The Sobbing Of The _____"?
questions.explanation:
Bells.

	"The Sobbing Of The Bells" was printed in 'Leaves Of Grass' in 1881.

questions.text: In which section of 'Leaves Of Grass' can the poem titled, "On The Beach At Night" be found?
questions.explanation:
Sea-Drift.

	The poem "On The Beach At Night" is in the final published section of 'Leaves Of Grass", called 'Sea-Drift'.

questions.text: In the poem, "Excelsior", what is the third question posted to the reader?
questions.explanation:
"What is most cautious?".

	"Who has gone farthest? for I would go farther,And who has been just? for I would be the most just person of the earth,And who most cautious? for I would be more cautious,And who has been happiest? O I think it is I - I think no one was ever happier than I,And who has lavish'd all? for I lavish constantly the best I have... And who thinks the amplest thoughts? for I would surround those thoughts,And who has made hymns fit for the earth? for I am mad with devouring ecstasy to make joyous hymns for the whole earth."

questions.text: In the poem, "On The Beach At Night", where were the father and daughter standing as they watched the autumn sky?
questions.explanation:
To the East.

	"On The Beach At Midnight" had its final edition written in 1871. It is part of the 'Sea Drift' section in 'Leaves Of Grass'.

questions.text: What year was the final edition of 'Leaves of Grass' published?
questions.explanation:
1892.

	There were sixteen sections of 'Leaves of Grass' in the final edition published in 1892. The last poem in the book was titled "Goodbye, My Fancy".
